Sure! Here's an example of how to calculate the unrealized profit in both scenarios:

1st option (10x leverage from beginning to end):

* Initial investment: $500
* Leveraged investment: $500 x 10 = $5000
* Initial price: $1000
* Current price: $900
* Unrealized profit: ($1000 - $900) x ($5000 / $1000) = $500

2nd option (10x leverage to start, changed to 15x when price was $950):

* Initial investment: $500
* Leveraged investment: $500 x 10 = $5000 (for the first part of the position)
* Initial price: $1000
* Price after change to 15x leverage: $950
* Leveraged investment after change: $550 x 15 = $8250 (for the second part of the position)
* Current price: $900
* Unrealized profit from first part of the position: ($1000 - $950) x ($5000 / $1000) = $250
* Unrealized profit from second part of the position: ($950 - $900) x ($8250 / $950) = $437.50
* Total unrealized profit: $250 + $437.50 = $687.50

In this example, you can see that the unrealized profit in the second scenario, where you changed the leverage to 15x when the price was $950, is higher ($687.50) compared to the first scenario where you used the 10x leverage from beginning to end ($500). This demonstrates how increasing leverage can magnify the potential gains on a trade, but also increases the risk of greater losses if the market moves against the position.
